Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stability and Dynamics of Antarctic Marine Outlet Glaciers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Van der Veen/1543530

The objective of this research is to gain better understanding of the West Antarctic ice flow in the transition region from grounded ice to floating ice shelves and investigate the conditions that can initiate and sustain major retreat of these glaciers. Several major Antarctic outlet glaciers and ice streams will be investigated using a suite of observational techniques and modeling tools. Glaciers include Thwaites Glacier, which has become a focal point in the discussion of West Antarctic retreat, Whillans Ice Stream as an example of the archetype ice stream, and Byrd Glacier, a major outlet glacier draining East Antarctica through the Transantarctic Mountains into the Ross Ice Shelf. This study will investigate whether the ongoing changes in these glaciers will lead to long-term mass loss (the onset of ice sheet collapse), or whether these glaciers will quickly stabilize with a new geometry.

To adequately incorporate the dynamic behavior of outlet glaciers and ice streams requires inclusion of the relevant physical processes, and the development of regional models that employ a numerical grid with a horizontal grid spacing sufficiently refined to capture smaller-scale bed topographic features that may control the flow of these glaciers. This award revisits the issue of stability of marine-terminating glaciers whose grounding line is located on a retrograded bed slope. In particular, an attempt will be made to resolve the question whether observed rapid changes are the result of perturbations at the terminus or grounding line, or whether these changes reflect ice-dynamical forcing over the grounded reaches. High-resolution satellite imagery will be used to investigate ice-flow perturbations on smaller spatial scales than has been done before, to evaluate the importance of localized sites of high basal resistance on grounding-line stability. This collaborative project involves a range of modeling strategies including force-budget analysis, flow-band modeling, Full Stokes modeling for local studies, and using the Ice Sheet System Model developed at JPL for regional modeling. Broader Impacts include training two graduate students in computer simulations and ice sheet modeling algorithms. The work will also expand on a web-based interactive flowline model, so that it includes more realistic grounding line dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award focused on glacier dynamics, or the study of motion under the action of forces. To better understand change, glaciologists often partition the forces resisting a glacier's motion according to the interfaces between a glacier and its surroundings. They are at the bed between ice and rock, at the margin between slow and faster moving ice, and at the floating ice shelf between ice and ocean. These forces act in concert, resisting the gravitational forces that motivate flow. Collectively, we refer to a 'balance of forces' as the sum of resistive and motivating forces. The sum is zero if glaciers are in equilibrium. Departures from a zero sum are responsible for changes in velocity. If the resisting forces are greater than gravitational, flow is slowing. As resistive forces diminish relative to gravitational forces, glaciers accelerate. 

 

Our primary concern was the role played by forces resulting from changes in the thickness and extent of the ice shelves. As our climate warms, warming oceans melt ice shelves. Thinner ice is more prone to calving, or breaking into icebergs. Thinner ice also leads to a retreat in the position where ice begins to float. The net effect is that more ice enters the ocean, contributing to sea level rise.
Previous modeling studies showed an abrupt reduction in forces from the ice shelf will not produce significant acceleration of a glacier because the forces aren't a large enough part of the overall budget. However, this is contrary to a large body of observational evidence suggesting that perturbations to the ice shelf correlate well with accelerating glaciers. We speculate that the system may be sensitive to even small perturbations in the force balance, because a perturbation in one place may lead to complex changes in the force balance across the glacier. This would explain the discrepancy between modeling and observation. With that in mind, we sought to study how perturbations to the force balance at the margins, bed, and on the ice shelf, would influence the motion and force balance of a glacier both immediately, and well into the future. 
We opened two lines of inquiry into the problem. First, we investigated satellite based observations of the glacier's surface and velocity. We were particularly interested in regions where the ice was not flowing downhill because the direction of motion in these areas had to be dictated by a strong imbalance in forces resisting gravity driven flow. We characterized regions of the ice sheet where these imbalances were occuring and sought out explanations for their locations. Then, through numerical modeling, we showed that the imbalances could not be arrived at within a conventional understanding of the partitioning of forces, and that explanation requires that the basal drag not be in the opposite direction to downhill. This is contrary to a large body of theory related to friction and glacier flow.

Second, we identified a marine glacier undergoing rapid changes and reproduced similar levels of change by forcing a numerical modeling with ocean driven melt. Initial model runs lead us to hypothesize that a glacier undergoing rapid changes is less sensitive to perturbations in the balance of forces than is a glacier that is undergoing modest changes, or a glacier in steady state.

Neither line of inquiry produced the high impact publications that we'd liked to have created. With each, there were difficulties with the approach and underlying data that lead to delays. In the case of the second hypothesis, we are still working towards publication of results.
